Since this country's founding, Americans could start over through bankruptcy. For those student borrowers who have no realistic path to pay back their student loan debt burden, bankruptcy should be available as an option to help them get back on their feet.

.@RepCicilline: "Far too many people across the country have been forced to take on massive and often insurmountable debt to pay for education. A college education cannot be a privilege just for the wealthiest few, but rather must be accessible to every student ..."

Chairman @RepJerryNadler: "This legislation updates the federal bankruptcy code to ensure student loan debt is treated like almost every other form of consumer debt that can be discharged during bankruptcy."
Chairman @RepJerryNadler: "We must ensure that Americans are able to invest in their education and then go on to live quality lives without the cloud of rising debt hanging over their heads."

The Student Borrower Bankruptcy Relief Act of 2022 would eliminate the section of the bankruptcy code that makes private and federal student loans nondischargeable, allowing these loans to be treated like nearly all other forms of consumer debt.

Recently, Chairman @RepJerryNadler and @RepCicilline introduced legislation that will give Americans overwhelmed by student loan debt the option of obtaining meaningful bankruptcy relief.
https://judiciary.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=5066

Forty-eight million Americans owe more than $1.75 trillion in student loan debt. Nondischargeable student debt is constraining the career and life choices of student borrowers, and analyses by the Federal Reserve show that the student debt burden is affecting the broader economy.

Americans face crushing student loan debt that prevents the pursuit of the American dream. Most forms of debt, such as credit card debt, can be discharged through bankruptcy. However, current federal law makes student loan debt nondischargeable except in extremely rare cases.

Together, we can support our senior community, and stop big pharma price gouging.

I was proud to work on passing these straightforward and long overdue changes that are a great step forward in making health care costs more affordable for every Rhode Islander. 8/8

All out-of-pocket costs for vaccines will be eliminated for Medicare Part D beneficiaries. Among the shots that will be fully covered is the shingles vaccine, which currently requires cost-sharing for those on Part D. 7/8
We also expanded eligibility for Medicare Part D Low-Income Subsidies to include incomes up to 150 percent of the poverty level, increasing benefits for 1,700 Rhode Islanders. 6/8
This law caps insulin costs at $35 per month for seniors and individuals with disabilities on Medicare. In 2020 alone, 11,000 Rhode Islanders on Medicare used insulin. 5/8

Seniors with Medicare Part D will see their out-of-pocket drug costs capped at $2,000 per year.

This means lower costs for more than 176,000 Rhode Islanders. Price should never prevent access to needed medicine. 4/8

It also cracks down on Big Pharma's price gouging.

Now, if drug companies raise prices for medications higher than the rate of inflation, they must pay rebates to Medicare for that value difference. 3/8

The Inflation Reduction Act empowers Medicare to negotiate drug prices for the first time in its history.

This means they can negotiate prices for the most expensive drugs, with projected savings of more than $100 billion for approximately 100 drugs over the next decade. 2/8

No one should be forced to ration medication or choose btwn a roof over their head & lifesaving care. Yet, too many RI seniors have been forced to make this impossible choice.

This August, I worked to pass the Inflation Reduction Act, to help protect seniors & their health. üßµ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Fe0SIozUYAAZKG-.jpg
